channel.title: Last Day - NEW & UPDATE
channel.description: All NEW and UPDATE articles from the last day with enhanced metadata

item.title: NEW: Microsoft Patches Actively Exploited Windows Zero-Day in Final 2025 Update
item.description:
Headline: Microsoft Patches Actively Exploited Windows Zero-Day in Final 2025 Update

Summary:
Microsoft's December 2025 Patch Tuesday addresses 57 vulnerabilities, including three zero-days. The most critical, CVE-2025-62221, is a privilege escalation flaw in the Windows Cloud Files Mini Filter Driver that is being actively exploited in the wild. This has prompted the U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) to add it to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog, mandating a patch by December 30, 2025. The flaw allows a local, authenticated attacker to gain SYSTEM-level privileges. The update also patches other critical RCE flaws in Microsoft Office and publicly disclosed, but not exploited, bugs in PowerShell and GitHub Copilot.

Severity: Critical

Categories: Patch Management, Vulnerability, Security Operations

Article Type: Advisory

Meta Description: Microsoft's December 2025 Patch Tuesday fixes an actively exploited zero-day vulnerability (CVE-2025-62221) in the Windows Cloud Files Mini Filter Driver, along with 56 other flaws.

Article Slug: microsoft-patches-actively-exploited-windows-zero-day-in-december-2025-update

Published Date: Thu, 18 Dec 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 18 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 18 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: Phishing Surge Hits Microsoft 365 via OAuth Device Code Abuse
item.description:
Headline: Phishing Surge Hits Microsoft 365 via OAuth Device Code Abuse

Summary:
Security researchers report a significant rise in phishing campaigns abusing the Microsoft OAuth 2.0 device authorization grant to compromise Microsoft 365 accounts. Both state-aligned groups like UNK_AcademicFlare and financially motivated actors like TA2723 are using this 'device code' phishing technique, often facilitated by Phishing-as-a-Service (PhaaS) kits like SquarePhish2. The attacks trick users into entering a short device code on Microsoft's legitimate 'microsoft.com/devicelogin' page, which inadvertently grants the attacker's malicious application a valid access token and persistent access to the victim's account.

Severity: High

Categories: Phishing, Threat Actor, Cloud Security

Article Type: NewsArticle

Meta Description: Threat actors are increasingly abusing the Microsoft OAuth device code flow in sophisticated phishing campaigns to gain unauthorized access to Microsoft 365 accounts.

Article Slug: threat-actors-abuse-oauth-device-code-flow-in-microsoft-365-phishing-surge

Published Date: Thu, 18 Dec 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 18 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 18 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: "GhostPoster" Malware Infects 50,000+ Firefox Users via Malicious Add-ons
item.description:
Headline: "GhostPoster" Malware Infects 50,000+ Firefox Users via Malicious Add-ons

Summary:
A stealthy malware campaign named "GhostPoster" has infected over 50,000 Mozilla Firefox users by distributing 17 malicious browser extensions. The add-ons, which masqueraded as legitimate tools like VPNs and ad blockers, have been removed from the Firefox store. The malware employed a clever technique, hiding obfuscated JavaScript within the add-on's logo image file. This code would then contact command-and-control (C2) servers to download a final payload designed for hijacking affiliate links and committing ad fraud. The campaign used evasion techniques like randomized and delayed C2 callbacks to avoid detection.

Severity: Medium

Categories: Malware, Cyberattack

Article Type: NewsArticle

Meta Description: The GhostPoster malware campaign has infected over 50,000 Mozilla Firefox users by hiding malicious JavaScript inside the logo files of 17 browser extensions.

Article Slug: ghostposter-malware-infects-50000-firefox-users-via-malicious-add-ons

Published Date: Thu, 18 Dec 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 18 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 18 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: "Scripted Sparrow" BEC Group Targets Finance Teams with Highly Structured Attacks
item.description:
Headline: "Scripted Sparrow" BEC Group Targets Finance Teams with Highly Structured Attacks

Summary:
A disciplined and persistent Business Email Compromise (BEC) group, newly identified by Fortra as "Scripted Sparrow," has been systematically targeting corporate finance teams since at least June 2024. The group employs a structured and well-researched approach, sending highly credible phishing emails with fake invoices that impersonate professional services firms. To add legitimacy, the attackers often include forged prior email correspondence from a company executive authorizing the payment. The group utilizes a large network of US-based mule accounts for cashing out, indicating a well-organized and persistent financial threat.

Severity: High

Categories: Threat Actor, Phishing, Cyberattack

Article Type: NewsArticle

Meta Description: A persistent and organized Business Email Compromise (BEC) group named Scripted Sparrow is targeting finance teams with convincing phishing emails and fake invoices.

Article Slug: scripted-sparrow-bec-group-targets-finance-teams-with-disciplined-phishing-attacks

Published Date: Thu, 18 Dec 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 18 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 18 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: "IRLeaks" Supply Chain Attack Hits Iranian Banks, Exposing Millions of Customer Records
item.description:
Headline: "IRLeaks" Supply Chain Attack Hits Iranian Banks, Exposing Millions of Customer Records

Summary:
A major supply chain attack dubbed "IRLeaks" has resulted in a significant data breach affecting several prominent Iranian banks and millions of their customers. Attackers first compromised a third-party IT vendor in October 2025, using it as a pivot point to infiltrate the banks' networks. Over the following month, they exfiltrated vast amounts of financial data and personally identifiable information (PII), including national IDs and bank account numbers, before the breach was discovered in late November. The incident highlights the critical risks associated with third-party vendor security and inadequate patch management.

Severity: High

Categories: Data Breach, Supply Chain Attack, Cyberattack

Article Type: NewsArticle

Meta Description: The "IRLeaks" data breach exposed millions of Iranian bank customers' data after attackers compromised a third-party IT service provider, highlighting significant supply chain risks.

Article Slug: irleaks-breach-at-iranian-banks-exposes-millions-via-third-party-vendor

Published Date: Thu, 18 Dec 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 18 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 18 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: Cloud Security Failing to Keep Pace with AI and Multicloud, Report Warns
item.description:
Headline: Cloud Security Failing to Keep Pace with AI and Multicloud, Report Warns

Summary:
A new report from Palo Alto Networks finds that cloud security operations are struggling to keep up with the rapid pace of multicloud adoption and AI integration. Attackers can now compromise cloud environments in minutes, while defenders take weeks to remediate critical issues. The report, which surveyed over 2,800 executives, highlights that identity and APIs are the top risk vectors, with 99% of organizations reporting at least one attack on their AI systems in the past year. It calls for a shift from fragmented security tools to integrated platforms to address the exponentially expanding attack surface.

Severity: Informational

Categories: Cloud Security, Policy and Compliance, Threat Intelligence

Article Type: Report

Meta Description: A Palo Alto Networks report reveals that cloud security is lagging behind the rapid expansion driven by AI and multicloud adoption, with attackers compromising environments in minutes.

Article Slug: cloud-security-failing-to-keep-pace-with-ai-and-multicloud-expansion

Published Date: Thu, 18 Dec 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 18 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 18 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: Ransomware Evolves: "ClickFix" Social Engineering and Threat Actor Alliances on the Rise
item.description:
Headline: Ransomware Evolves: "ClickFix" Social Engineering and Threat Actor Alliances on the Rise

Summary:
A December 2025 threat report from NCC Group indicates that while ransomware attack volumes plateaued in November with 583 incidents, their sophistication markedly increased. Attackers are increasingly adopting the "ClickFix" (also known as ClearFake) social engineering technique, which tricks users into manually running malicious commands, bypassing many automated defenses. The report also highlights a trend of collaboration, with groups like DragonForce forming alliances with skilled affiliates from other networks. The Qilin ransomware group remained the most prolific actor, with the industrials sector and North America being the most targeted.

Severity: High

Categories: Ransomware, Threat Actor, Threat Intelligence

Article Type: Report

Meta Description: Ransomware tactics are evolving with the rise of the "ClickFix" social engineering technique and increased collaboration between threat groups like Qilin and DragonForce, according to a new report.

Article Slug: ransomware-tactics-evolve-in-2025-with-focus-on-human-operated-attacks

Published Date: Thu, 18 Dec 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 18 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 18 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: AI-Powered Ransomware "PromptLock" and Petya Successor "HybridPetya" Emerge
item.description:
Headline: AI-Powered Ransomware "PromptLock" and Petya Successor "HybridPetya" Emerge

Summary:
ESET's H2 2025 threat report confirms the shift of AI-powered malware from theory to reality with the discovery of "PromptLock," the first known AI-driven ransomware capable of generating malicious scripts on the fly. The report also details the emergence of "HybridPetya," a modern successor to the destructive Petya/NotPetya wiper that is now capable of compromising UEFI-based systems. Other key trends from the second half of 2025 include the dominance of the Akira and Qilin RaaS operations and a massive surge in the CloudEyE (GuLoader) malware downloader, which saw its detections increase almost thirtyfold.

Severity: High

Categories: Malware, Ransomware, Threat Intelligence

Article Type: Report

Meta Description: ESET's H2 2025 threat report details the emergence of AI-powered ransomware "PromptLock," a new Petya variant "HybridPetya," and the dominance of the Akira and Qilin RaaS groups.

Article Slug: ai-powered-malware-and-petya-successor-emerge-in-h2-2025-threat-landscape

Published Date: Thu, 18 Dec 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 18 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 18 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: "Operation ForumTroll" APT Targets Russian Academics with Plagiarism Lure
item.description:
Headline: "Operation ForumTroll" APT Targets Russian Academics with Plagiarism Lure

Summary:
The Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) group known as Operation ForumTroll has launched a new, highly targeted phishing campaign aimed at Russian political scientists and academics. Active since at least 2022, the group's latest attack uses meticulously crafted emails impersonating a major Russian scientific library, eLibrary.ru. The emails lure victims into downloading a supposed plagiarism report, which is a ZIP archive containing a malicious .LNK file. Executing the shortcut file triggers a PowerShell script that downloads and installs the Tuoni command-and-control (C2) framework, giving the attackers remote access for espionage purposes.

Severity: High

Categories: Threat Actor, Phishing, Cyberattack

Article Type: NewsArticle

Meta Description: The APT group Operation ForumTroll is targeting Russian academics with a new phishing campaign that uses fake plagiarism reports to deploy the Tuoni C2 framework.

Article Slug: operation-forumtroll-apt-targets-russian-academics-with-new-phishing-campaign

Published Date: Thu, 18 Dec 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 18 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 18 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: Google Investigates Malicious Code Found in Search Result Infrastructure
item.description:
Headline: Google Investigates Malicious Code Found in Search Result Infrastructure

Summary:
Google has launched an urgent investigation after cybersecurity analysts discovered anomalous, encrypted code snippets and obfuscated JavaScript embedded within its core search result payloads on December 17, 2025. The malicious code appears designed to exploit browser sandboxing vulnerabilities, which could potentially enable remote code execution or data theft on users' systems. While Google has not confirmed any user impact and states it is neutralizing the threat, the incident represents a highly sophisticated attack against critical global internet infrastructure, prompting the involvement of government agencies.

Severity: Critical

Categories: Cyberattack, Data Breach, Security Operations

Article Type: NewsArticle

Meta Description: Google is investigating a potential security breach after malicious code and suspicious scripts were found embedded within its core search result infrastructure.

Article Slug: google-investigates-malicious-code-anomaly-in-search-results-infrastructure

Published Date: Thu, 18 Dec 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 18 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 18 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: UPDATE: 2025: The Year Cybersecurity 'Crossed the AI Rubicon'
item.description:
Headline: 2025: The Year Cybersecurity 'Crossed the AI Rubicon'

Summary:
According to analysis published on December 14, 2025, the year 2025 represents a fundamental and irreversible turning point for the cybersecurity industry. The widespread integration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) into both offensive and defensive strategies has permanently altered the threat landscape. Key trends include the rise of 'agentic AI' capable of autonomous attacks, adaptive threats that change tactics in real-time, and a surge in highly convincing, AI-generated phishing and deepfake content. While defenders are also adopting AI, the 'great acceleration' in threat complexity is forcing a complete rethink of security playbooks.

Severity: Informational

Categories: Threat Intelligence, Other

Article Type: Analysis

Meta Description: A 2025 year-in-review analysis concludes that the integration of artificial intelligence into both cyberattacks and defense strategies has permanently altered the threat landscape.

Article Slug: 2025-the-year-ai-redefines-cyberattacks-and-defense

Published Date: Sun, 14 Dec 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Sun, 14 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 18 Dec 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Update Count: 1

Update History: 1 update recorded

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: React2Shell RCE Flaw (CVSS 10.0) Under Mass Exploitation by State Actors and Cybercriminals
item.description:
Headline: React2Shell RCE Flaw (CVSS 10.0) Under Mass Exploitation by State Actors and Cybercriminals

Summary:
A critical, unauthenticated remote code execution (RCE) vulnerability in React Server Components, tracked as CVE-2025-55182 and dubbed 'React2Shell,' is being actively and widely exploited. With a CVSS score of 10.0, the flaw allows attackers to take full control of vulnerable servers, including those using popular frameworks like Next.js. Microsoft and Google have observed hundreds of compromises, with threat actors ranging from Chinese state-sponsored espionage groups to financially motivated criminals. Attackers are deploying Linux backdoors like KSwapDoor, crypto miners such as XMRig, and stealing cloud credentials for Azure, AWS, and GCP. Urgent patching is required as exploitation began as early as December 5, 2025.

Severity: Critical

Categories: Vulnerability, Cyberattack, Threat Actor

Article Type: Advisory

Keywords: CVE-2025-55182, React2Shell, React Server Components vulnerability, Next.js exploit, remote code execution, KSwapDoor malware, UNC6600, CVSS 10.0, cybersecurity alert, patch management

Reading Time: 6 minutes

Meta Description: Urgent alert on CVE-2025-55182 (React2Shell), a critical 10.0 CVSS RCE vulnerability in React Server Components actively exploited by nation-states and criminals. Learn how to detect and mitigate the threat.

Article Slug: widespread-exploitation-of-critical-react2shell-vulnerability-triggers-urgent-patching

Published Date: Wed, 17 Dec 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Wed, 17 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Wed, 17 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: AI Adoption Fuels 'Massive' Cloud Attack Surface Expansion, Palo Alto Networks Report Warns
item.description:
Headline: AI Adoption Fuels 'Massive' Cloud Attack Surface Expansion, Palo Alto Networks Report Warns

Summary:
Palo Alto Networks' 2025 'State of Cloud Security Report' reveals that the rapid adoption of AI is creating an unprecedented expansion of the cloud attack surface. The study, surveying 2,800 security leaders, found that 99% of organizations have had their AI systems attacked in the last year. The use of generative AI in coding is producing insecure code faster than security teams can remediate it, creating a significant risk gap. API attacks have surged by 41% year-over-year, and lenient identity and access management (IAM) remains a top vulnerability. The report calls for a unified, platform-based approach to cloud security to counter AI-weaponized threats.

Severity: Informational

Categories: Cloud Security, Threat Intelligence, Policy and Compliance

Article Type: Report

Keywords: cloud security report, AI security, Palo Alto Networks, cloud attack surface, API attacks, generative AI risks, IAM security, CNAPP

Reading Time: 5 minutes

Meta Description: Palo Alto Networks' 2025 cloud security report finds that rapid AI adoption is creating a massive surge in cloud risks, with 99% of organizations reporting attacks on their AI systems.

Article Slug: palo-alto-networks-report-ai-driving-massive-expansion-of-cloud-attack-surface

Published Date: Wed, 17 Dec 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Wed, 17 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Wed, 17 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: French Interior Ministry Confirms Cyberattack Compromised Email Servers
item.description:
Headline: French Interior Ministry Confirms Cyberattack Compromised Email Servers

Summary:
The French Ministry of the Interior has confirmed its email servers were compromised in a cyberattack detected between December 11 and 12, 2025. Interior Minister Laurent Nuñez stated that attackers stole staff email passwords, allowing them to access an unknown number of document files. While the government is still assessing the scale, a hacker group named 'Indra' has claimed, without evidence, to have exfiltrated police files on 16.4 million citizens. In response, the ministry is rolling out two-factor authentication and resetting passwords. The attack on the high-value government target, which oversees national police and security, has raised speculation of nation-state involvement, with groups like APT28 being considered.

Severity: High

Categories: Data Breach, Cyberattack, Threat Actor

Article Type: NewsArticle

Keywords: French Interior Ministry hack, cyberattack France, government data breach, Indra hacker group, APT28, email server compromise, MFA, Laurent Nuñez

Reading Time: 5 minutes

Meta Description: The French Ministry of the Interior confirms a major cyberattack compromised its email servers, leading to a data breach. Attackers stole credentials and accessed files, with investigations ongoing.

Article Slug: french-interior-ministry-confirms-cyberattack-on-email-servers

Published Date: Wed, 17 Dec 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Wed, 17 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Wed, 17 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: CISA Adds Actively Exploited Fortinet SSO Flaw to KEV Catalog, Urges Immediate Patching
item.description:
Headline: CISA Adds Actively Exploited Fortinet SSO Flaw to KEV Catalog, Urges Immediate Patching

Summary:
The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added a critical Fortinet vulnerability, CVE-2025-59718, to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog, indicating active attacks in the wild. The flaw, rated 9.1 CVSS, allows an unauthenticated attacker to bypass FortiCloud single sign-on (SSO) authentication on multiple products, including FortiOS and FortiProxy, by sending a crafted SAML message. Security firm Arctic Wolf observed attackers exploiting the flaw within days of its disclosure to export device configurations and harvest credentials. CISA has mandated that federal agencies patch by December 23, 2025, and strongly advises all organizations to apply updates or disable the feature immediately.

Severity: Critical

Categories: Vulnerability, Patch Management, Cyberattack

Article Type: Advisory

Keywords: CVE-2025-59718, CISA KEV, Fortinet vulnerability, FortiCloud SSO exploit, authentication bypass, FortiOS patch, Arctic Wolf, cybersecurity alert

Reading Time: 5 minutes

Meta Description: CISA adds critical Fortinet SSO bypass vulnerability CVE-2025-59718 to its KEV catalog due to active exploitation. Learn how to patch affected FortiOS, FortiProxy, and FortiWeb devices now.

Article Slug: cisa-adds-actively-exploited-fortinet-sso-vulnerability-to-kev-catalog

Published Date: Wed, 17 Dec 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Wed, 17 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Wed, 17 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: New 'ConsentFix' Phishing Attack Hijacks Microsoft Accounts, Bypassing MFA via Azure CLI Abuse
item.description:
Headline: New 'ConsentFix' Phishing Attack Hijacks Microsoft Accounts, Bypassing MFA via Azure CLI Abuse

Summary:
A novel and sophisticated phishing attack dubbed 'ConsentFix' allows attackers to hijack Microsoft accounts without stealing passwords or bypassing multi-factor authentication (MFA). Discovered by Push Security, the browser-native attack tricks users into completing a fake verification process that involves copying a URL containing a sensitive OAuth authorization code from their browser's address bar and pasting it into the attacker's phishing page. The attacker then uses this code to authenticate as the user via the legitimate and trusted Microsoft Azure Command-Line Interface (CLI). Because the Azure CLI is a first-party app, it bypasses many consent restrictions, granting the attacker full account access. The technique is active and circumvents even phishing-resistant authentication like passkeys.

Severity: High

Categories: Phishing, Cloud Security, Threat Actor

Article Type: Analysis

Keywords: ConsentFix attack, ClickFix, OAuth phishing, Azure CLI exploit, MFA bypass, Microsoft account hijack, Push Security, browser-native attack

Reading Time: 5 minutes

Meta Description: A new 'ConsentFix' phishing attack bypasses MFA to hijack Microsoft accounts by tricking users into pasting an OAuth authorization code, which is then used with the trusted Azure CLI.

Article Slug: new-consentfix-phishing-attack-bypasses-mfa-to-hijack-microsoft-accounts

Published Date: Wed, 17 Dec 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Wed, 17 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Wed, 17 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: New Zealand Launches Massive Public Alert, Warning 26,000 Citizens of Lumma Stealer Malware Infections
item.description:
Headline: New Zealand Launches Massive Public Alert, Warning 26,000 Citizens of Lumma Stealer Malware Infections

Summary:
In a first-of-its-kind campaign, New Zealand's National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) is emailing approximately 26,000 people to warn them of potential infection by the Lumma Stealer malware. The potent information-stealing software targets Windows devices to covertly harvest sensitive data, including passwords, browser credentials, banking details, and cryptocurrency wallets. Officials have confirmed that some of the stolen credentials were linked to government and banking systems, heightening the risk of fraud. The NCSC's mass notification directs affected individuals to a government website with instructions for malware removal and improving account security.

Severity: High

Categories: Malware, Phishing, Data Breach

Article Type: NewsArticle

Keywords: Lumma Stealer, New Zealand malware, NCSC alert, information stealer, password theft, cybersecurity New Zealand, Windows malware, data breach

Reading Time: 4 minutes

Meta Description: New Zealand's National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) warns 26,000 citizens of potential infection by Lumma Stealer, a potent info-stealing malware targeting Windows devices for sensitive data.

Article Slug: new-zealand-warns-26000-citizens-of-lumma-stealer-malware-infections

Published Date: Wed, 17 Dec 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Wed, 17 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Wed, 17 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: MITRE Extends D3FEND Cybersecurity Framework to Operational Technology (OT)
item.description:
Headline: MITRE Extends D3FEND Cybersecurity Framework to Operational Technology (OT)

Summary:
MITRE has officially extended its D3FEND cybersecurity framework to include Operational Technology (OT), providing a standardized knowledge base of defensive techniques for cyber-physical systems. Announced on December 16, 2025, the NSA-funded initiative aims to create a common language for securing critical infrastructure in sectors like energy, manufacturing, and defense. As OT systems become increasingly connected to IT networks, D3FEND for OT provides a structured ontology of countermeasures tailored to the unique components and risks of industrial environments, mapping defensive techniques to threats against controllers, sensors, and actuators.

Severity: Informational

Categories: Industrial Control Systems, Policy and Compliance, Security Operations

Article Type: NewsArticle

Keywords: MITRE D3FEND, D3FEND for OT, Operational Technology security, ICS cybersecurity, cyber-physical systems, critical infrastructure protection, defensive cybersecurity, NSA

Reading Time: 4 minutes

Meta Description: MITRE extends its D3FEND cybersecurity framework to include Operational Technology (OT), creating a standardized knowledge base for defending critical infrastructure and industrial control systems.

Article Slug: mitre-extends-d3fend-cybersecurity-framework-to-operational-technology-ot

Published Date: Wed, 17 Dec 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Wed, 17 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Wed, 17 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: Apple and Google Issue Global Warnings Over Mercenary Spyware Attacks
item.description:
Headline: Apple and Google Issue Global Warnings Over Mercenary Spyware Attacks

Summary:
Apple and Google have issued a new round of threat notifications to users across the globe, warning them of targeted attacks by state-sponsored and mercenary spyware groups. Google's alert on December 3rd specifically called out the continued operations of Intellexa, a sanctioned surveillance vendor, and its 'Predator' spyware, which is being delivered via new zero-day exploits. Google warned several hundred users in countries like Pakistan, Egypt, and Saudi Arabia. Apple also sent a batch of warnings on December 2nd to users in over 150 countries, continuing its policy of notifying high-risk individuals such as journalists and activists who are prime targets for such sophisticated surveillance.

Severity: High

Categories: Threat Actor, Malware, Mobile Security

Article Type: NewsArticle

Keywords: mercenary spyware, Predator spyware, Intellexa, Apple threat notification, Google spyware warning, state-sponsored hacking, zero-day exploit, mobile security

Reading Time: 5 minutes

Meta Description: Apple and Google issue a new wave of global threat notifications, warning high-risk users of attacks by mercenary spyware groups like Intellexa and its 'Predator' spyware.

Article Slug: apple-and-google-warn-global-users-of-mercenary-spyware-attacks

Published Date: Wed, 17 Dec 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Wed, 17 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Wed, 17 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: Push Security Launches Tool to Block Malicious 'ClickFix' Copy-Paste Attacks
item.description:
Headline: Push Security Launches Tool to Block Malicious 'ClickFix' Copy-Paste Attacks

Summary:
Push Security has launched a new 'malicious copy-and-paste detection' feature to combat the rapidly growing threat of 'ClickFix' style attacks. Announced on December 17, 2025, the browser-based tool is designed to stop social engineering attacks where users are tricked into copying malicious code from a website and pasting it into a terminal or command prompt. With reports of a 517% surge in such attacks, the new feature works by analyzing copy events in the browser, blocking malicious scripts from being copied to the clipboard, and effectively disarming the attack before the payload can be executed by the user.

Severity: Informational

Categories: Security Operations, Phishing, Threat Intelligence

Article Type: NewsArticle

Keywords: Push Security, ClickFix attack, malicious copy and paste, browser security, social engineering, phishing prevention, cybersecurity tool

Reading Time: 3 minutes

Meta Description: Push Security launches a new malicious copy-and-paste detection feature to block 'ClickFix' social engineering attacks, where users are tricked into running malicious code from their browser.

Article Slug: push-security-launches-tool-to-block-clickfix-malicious-copy-paste-attacks

Published Date: Wed, 17 Dec 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Wed, 17 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Wed, 17 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: 'Operation MoneyMount-ISO' Phishing Campaign Deploys Phantom Stealer via Malicious ISOs
item.description:
Headline: 'Operation MoneyMount-ISO' Phishing Campaign Deploys Phantom Stealer via Malicious ISOs

Summary:
A financially motivated, Russian-language phishing campaign dubbed 'Operation MoneyMount-ISO' is actively targeting finance and accounting departments to deploy the Phantom information-stealing malware. According to researchers at Seqrite Labs, the attack uses emails with fake payment confirmations that contain a malicious ISO disk image file. This technique is designed to bypass email security controls. When the user opens the ISO, it mounts a virtual drive with a disguised executable. Running this file triggers a memory-resident infection chain that deploys Phantom Stealer, which then harvests browser credentials, crypto wallets, and other sensitive data for exfiltration.

Severity: High

Categories: Phishing, Malware, Threat Actor

Article Type: Analysis

Keywords: Phantom Stealer, Operation MoneyMount-ISO, ISO phishing, Seqrite Labs, information stealer, malware campaign, finance department attack, email security

Reading Time: 5 minutes

Meta Description: A Russian-language phishing campaign, 'Operation MoneyMount-ISO,' uses malicious ISO files to deploy Phantom Stealer malware, targeting finance departments to steal credentials and crypto wallets.

Article Slug: operation-moneymount-iso-phishing-campaign-deploys-phantom-stealer

Published Date: Wed, 17 Dec 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Wed, 17 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Wed, 17 Dec 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: UPDATE: Storm-0249 Evolves: Access Broker Now Deploys Ransomware with Advanced Stealth Tactics
item.description:
Headline: Storm-0249 Evolves: Access Broker Now Deploys Ransomware with Advanced Stealth Tactics

Summary:
The initial access broker (IAB) known as Storm-0249 is evolving its tactics, moving beyond simply selling network access to actively participating in malware deployment. According to ReliaQuest, the group now uses more sophisticated techniques, including DLL side-loading and fileless PowerShell execution, to facilitate ransomware attacks directly. Their methods involve social engineering victims into running malicious commands (`ClickFix`), which fetch and execute PowerShell scripts from spoofed domains. A key technique is dropping a trojanized version of a SentinelOne security agent DLL to run malware under the guise of a trusted process. This evolution signifies a dangerous trend where IABs are becoming more integrated into the ransomware deployment process, increasing their threat level.
